title: The Goofy Gophers
descriptions:
The Goofy Gophers (1947) is a Looney Tunes short centered on two impeccably polite gophers whose refined manners clash comically with a hungry dog guarding a vegetable garden. The film opens with the gophers discovering a lush patch of produce—carrots, lettuce, and other treats—nestled behind a fence. With genteel courtesy, they address one another as “After you,” “No, after you,” signaling their signature gag: a relentless exchange of refinement even while plotting mischief.

Their plan to raid the garden runs into an obstacle: a burly, dim-witted guard dog assigned to keep pests out. The gophers’ approach to outsmarting him relies not on brute force but on elaborate, absurdly courteous trickery. They repeatedly feign innocence, congratulate each other on clever ideas, and deploy slapstick tactics delivered with an air of classical gentility—comically formal dialogue paired with cartoon violence.

In one sequence, the gophers sneak in under the fence, only to be spotted by the dog. A chase ensues through rows of vegetables, but the pair stays cool, pausing to offer each other the first bite of a carrot as the dog barrels past. They exploit his momentum with rakes, garden hoses, and precisely timed doors, making him crash, tumble, and sputter. Even as they set traps—like placing a rake that flips up into the dog’s face—they graciously apologize for the inconvenience, as if the chaos were an unfortunate social faux pas.

The dog tries intimidation tactics, growling and posturing, only to be baffled by their politeness. When he corners them, they flatter his intelligence, distractedly introduce a fake “official” sign, or present him with a bouquet of carrots, allowing them to slip away. One gag has them infiltrating the dog’s doghouse, reemerging in costume to confuse him—at one point adopting dignified airs like maître d’s, guiding him right into a wheelbarrow that catapults him over the fence.

The escalating battle of wits pushes the dog to scheme more elaborately. He rigs a trap with a string and a suspended rake, only to be caught by his own snare. He plants himself beside the vegetables, vowing not to budge, and the gophers respond with psychological warfare: whispering, tiptoeing, and performing a mock “symphony” of clinks and clatters that frays his nerves. Their unfailingly polite banter—offering the dog the first chance to chase them—amplifies the absurdity.

In a hallmark sequence, the gophers operate like tiny engineers. They set up a pulley system and create a mechanical line for transporting vegetables out from under the dog’s nose. As he follows a decoy carrot that moves just ahead of him, he tumbles into a watering trough; the gophers graciously hand him a towel before sprinting off with armloads of produce. When he tries to tunnel after them, they reverse the gag, popping up behind him with “Pardon us,” and sending him into his own hole.

The short culminates in a series of rapid-fire reversals. The dog sets a final trap: he pretends to sleep with a net at the ready. The gophers counter by staging an exaggeratedly quiet heist, tiptoeing with opera-glass seriousness. At the precise moment the net drops, they’re already elsewhere, having substituted a scarecrow. The dog gathers his strength for one last pounce and charges straight through a fence and into a tree. Dazed and defeated, he surrenders.

In the closing stretch, the gophers, still unfailingly polite, offer the dog a peace treaty—perhaps a carrot or a pat—before whisking away with their harvest. They exchange one final round of “After you,” “No, after you,” as they retreat underground, leaving the garden pristine save for the dog’s bewildered footprints and a few toppled tools.

Throughout, the short’s humor hinges on the contrast between refined manners and slapstick chaos. The gophers’ prim diction, synchronized movements, and gentlemanly interjections turn each gag into a comedy of decorum triumphing over brawn. The dog, while aggressive, is less a villain than a foil—forever a step behind their dainty, devastating cleverness. The film ends with the gophers enjoying their spoils in their burrow, still deferring to each other with comical politeness as they nibble on carrots, their victory sealed not by force, but by courtesy and cunning.
